messages.content: Can you tell me the notes for a short, famous melody?

Certainly! One short, famous melody is "Beethoven's Symphony No. 5" which starts with the iconic notes:

G - G - G - E♭ / F - F - F - D

This is the famous "da-da-da-dum" motif that has become synonymous with Beethoven's work. Keep in mind that these are the simplified, single-note versions of the melody, and the actual piece is more complex and orchestral.
Can you pick any famous melody that was composed in the 20th century?

Sure! One well-known melody from the 20th century is "Somewhere Over the Rainbow" from the 1939 film "The Wizard of Oz," composed by Harold Arlen.

Here are the starting notes for the melody:

C - C - D - E♭ - E♭ - D - E♭ - C - A♭ - B♭ - A♭ - G - A♭

These notes are for the iconic line, "Somewhere over the rainbow, way up high." Keep in mind that this is a simplified, single-note version of the melody, and the actual piece is more elaborate and harmonious.
Can you give name of each note and their octave and duration for an iconic line from that melody?

Certainly! Here's the iconic line "Somewhere over the rainbow" from the melody, with their octave, note names, and duration (assuming the key is in C Major):

1. C4 (quarter note)
2. C4 (eighth note)
3. D4 (eighth note)
4. E♭4 (quarter note)
5. E♭4 (quarter note)
6. D4 (eighth note)
7. E♭4 (eighth note)
8. C4 (quarter note)
9. A♭3 (quarter note)
10. B♭3 (quarter note)
11. A♭3 (eighth note)
12. G3 (eighth note)
13. A♭3 (quarter note)

This is a simplified version of the melody and may vary slightly depending on the arrangement or specific performance. Make sure to adjust the octave numbers according to the instrument or voice you're using.
